It deals with the violent, sadistic and homoerotic tendencies of a group of boys at an Austrian military academy at the beginning of the 20th century.

starring: Amy Brenneman;Aaron Eckhart;Catherine Keener;Nastassja Kinski;Jason Patric;Ben Stiller
desc: Your Friends & Neighbors is a 1998 black comedy film[4] written and directed by Neil LaBute and starring Amy Brenneman, Aaron Eckhart, Catherine Keener, Nastassja Kinski, Jason Patric, and Ben Stiller in an ensemble cast. This film was the first to be reviewed on the website Rotten Tomatoes. The film's credit sequences feature music by Apocalyptica.

Yours Emotionally is a United Kingdom-Indian co-produced film with a gay theme. The film was selected for participation in LGBT film festivals in San Francisco (Frameline, formerly the San Francisco International Lesbian and Gay Film Festival), New York (NewFest), Amsterdam and others.

starring: Caroline Azar;Donna Dresch;Leslie Mah;Beverly Breckenridge;Jena von Brücker;G.B. Jones;Bruce LaBruce;Deke Nihilson
desc: The Yo-Yo Gang is a 1992 Canadian 'exploitation film' about girl gangs. Directed by G.B. Jones, the thirty-minute 'no budget film' follows the exploits of two girl gangs, the "Yo-Yo Gang" and the "Skateboard Bitches", as a gangwar erupts between them. The tag line for the film reads: "Gang girls frequently out-curse, out-fight and out-sex every boys' gang around".

directed_by: 百合子, ダスヴィダーニヤ
starring: Nobuko;by Yuriko Miyamoto;Yuriko, dasuvidāniya: Yuasa Yoshiko no seishun;by Hitomi Sawabe
desc: Yuriko, Dasvidaniya (百合子、ダスヴィダーニヤ) (Yoshiko & Yuriko) is a 2011 Japanese biographical drama directed by Sachi Hamano.
Yuriko's Aroma (ユリ子のアロマ, Yuriko no Aroma) is a 2010 Japanese erotic comedy drama film directed by Kōta Yoshida. It was released on May 8.[1]
Yuwakusha (誘惑者) ([The Enchantment] error: {{lang-xx}}: text has italic markup (help)) is a 1989 Japanese film directed by Shuichi Nagasaki.

Cruel Female Love Suicide (残酷おんな情死, Zankoku onna jōshi) is an April 1970 Japanese film directed by Shōgorō Nishimura and starring Annu Mari and Sanae Ōhori. The major Japanese film studio Nikkatsu began to experiment with erotic-themed movies beginning in the late 1960s in an attempt to save the company from insolvency. Cruel Female Love Suicide continued this trend which eventually resulted in the inauguration of Nikkatsu's Roman porno series of films in November 1971 with Apartment Wife: Affair In the Afternoon, also directed by Shōgorō Nishimura.[1]
Zenne Dancer is a 2012 Turkish drama film directed by Caner Alper and Mehmet Binay.

starring: John Robinson;Normand Fauteux;Dianne Heatherington;Richardo Keens-Douglas;Michael Callen;Marla Lukofsky;Von Flores
desc: Zero Patience is a 1993 Canadian musical film written and directed by John Greyson. The film examines and refutes the urban legend of the alleged introduction of HIV to North America by a single individual, Gaëtan Dugas. Dugas, better known as Patient Zero, was tagged in the popular imagination with the blame in large measure because of Randy Shilts's history of the early days of the AIDS epidemic, And the Band Played On (1987). The film tells its story against the backdrop of a romance between a time-displaced Sir Richard Francis Burton and the ghost of "Zero" (the character is not identified by Dugas' name).

produced_by: Gregory Lanesey;Matt Radecki;Martin Curland;Alan Grossbard;Jay Whitney Brown
starring: Taylor Handley;Gina Bellman;Kyle Schmid;Kelly Le Brock
desc: Zerophilia is a 2005 romantic comedy film with speculative-fiction elements directed by Academy of Motion Pictures' Student Academy Award-winning director Martin Curland and produced by Microangelo Entertainment. It is about a young man who discovers that he has a genetic condition which will cause a change of sex following each orgasm.
ZMD: Zombies of Mass Destruction is a 2010 zombie comedy film directed by Kevin Hamedani.[2]

Zorro, The Gay Blade is a 1981 swashbuckling comedy film from 20th Century Fox, produced by C.O. Erickson and George Hamilton, directed by Peter Medak, that stars George Hamilton, Lauren Hutton, Ron Leibman, and Brenda Vaccaro. Via its dedication to director Rouben Mamoulian and opening prologue, the film establishes that it is a sequel to 20th Century Fox's swashbuckling adventure film The Mark of Zorro (1940).

starring: Monic Hendrickx;Anneke Blok;Sylvia Poorta;Jacob Derwig;Halina Reijn
desc: Zus & Zo is a 2001 Dutch film directed by Paula van der Oest. It was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.
